greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Total sum T(n,k) of parts <= n of multiplicity k in all partitions of n; triangle T(n,k), n>=0, 0<=k<=n, read by rows.
comment: For k > 0, column k is asymptotic to sqrt(3) * (2*k+1) * exp(Pi*sqrt(2*n/3)) / (2 * k^2 * (k+1)^2 * Pi^2) ~ 6 * (2*k+1) * n * p(n) / (k^2 * (k+1)^2 * Pi^2), where p(n) is the partition function A000041(n). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, May 29 2018
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
example: The partitions of n=4 are [1,1,1,1], [2,1,1], [2,2], [3,1], [4].  Parts <= 4 with multiplicity m=0 sum up to (2+3+4)+(3+4)+(1+3+4)+(2+4)+(1+2+3) = 36, for m=1 the sum is 2+(3+1)+4 = 10, for m=2 the sum is 1+2 = 3, for m=3 the sum is 0, for m=4 the sum is 1 => row 4 = [36, 10, 3, 0, 1].
maple: b:= proc(n, p) option remember; `if`(n=0 and p=0, [1, 0],
mathematica: b[n_, p_] := b[n, p] = If[n == 0 && p == 0, {1, 0}, If[p == 0, Array[0&, n+2], Sum[Function[l, ReplacePart[l, m+2 -> p*l[[1]] + l[[m+2]]]][Join[b[n - p*m, p-1] , Array[0&, p*m]]], {m, 0, n/p}]]]; Rest /@ Table[b[n, n], {n, 0, 14}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 16 2013, translated from Maple *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 03 2013
